item.description: n— title: “Annualized Rate of Occurrence” tags: seed security An expression of the Likelihood of a risk as the number of times per year a particular loss is expected to occur.

item.title: 3-2-1 Rule
item.description: A data storage principle that states that your should have 3 copies of your data, across 2 media types, with one copy held offline and offsite.

item.title: Aggregation or Banding
item.description: Database Deidentification Methods that involve generalizing data to make it less specific, such as turning specific values into ranges

item.title: Agile Approach
item.description: The Agile Approach involves developing and implementing code piece-by-piece on a continuous basis. It usually involves breaking up each task that a program should accomplish and tackling each one individually.

item.title: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act
item.description: A wide-ranging act passed in 2009 that authorized $787 billion in spending and tax cuts over a 10-year period. Title XIII includes strong privacy provisions for Electronic Health Records, banning the sale of health information and promoting the use of audit trails and encryption and providing rights of access for patients.

item.title: Annualized Loss Expectancy
item.description: The amount that would be lost over the course of a year. Determined by multiplying the Single Loss Expectancy by the Annualized Rate of Occurrence

item.title: Backups
item.description: The practice of creating and storing copies of data in order to allow data restoration in the event of a failure or loss of the original data.

item.title: Breach of Contract
item.description: When one party fails to meet the terms of a contract

item.title: Bribery
item.description: Bribes are things given that are made in secret, indirectly through a third party, and encourage an obligation for the recipient to act favorably toward the donor

item.title: Business Case
item.description: A written document or report that helps executive management and key stakeholders determine the benefits and rewards of the Project. The elements of a Business Case include:

item.title: Call List
item.description: A document listing authorized contacts for notification and collaboration during a security incident.

item.title: Cash Flow Techniques
item.description: Provide data on the overall financials of the alternative solutions or projects. Each of these techniques rely on the concept of time value of money.

item.title: Chain of Custody
item.description: The record of evidence history from collection, to presentation in court, to disposal

item.title: CIA Triad
item.description: Confidentiality The privacy and secrecy of a thing, AKA only accessible by authorized and authenticated users Integrity The data is ensured to be unaltered; it is exactly what it was, and all changes are authorized and audited Availability The data is accessible for those who need it and are allowed to access it

item.title: CIRT
item.description: Cyber Incident Response Team A dedicated team that acts as a single point-of-contact for the notification of security events. Also know as Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT) or Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT)

item.title: Clinical Decision Support
item.description: A process and a set of tolls designed to enhance healthcare-related decision making through the use of clinical knowledge and patient-specific information to improve healthcare delivery.

item.title: Closing
item.description: The primary purpose of the closing phase is to validate deliverables and document the formal acceptance of the project work. Once that’s complete, a handoff occurs whereby the completed product or result of the project is turned over to the organization for ongoing maintenance and support.

item.title: Communication Plan
item.description: A policy implemented to effectively communicate a security incident. The goal is to communicate to necessary parties only, to avoid alerting attackers as well.

item.title: Communications Decency Act
item.description: Part of the Telecommunications Act Its primary purpose was to allow free competition among phone, cable, and TV companies. Title V is specifically aimed at protecting children from pornography.

item.title: Community Cloud
item.description: Community clouds are a type of cloud computing where the cloud is available to be used by a community. It can also be called a public cloud.

item.title: Conflict of Interest
item.description: A conflict between someone’s self-interest and the client’s interest

item.title: Consequentialism
item.description: The philosophy of weighing the morality of actions on the basis of their probably outcomes or consequences See also: Utilitarianism

item.title: Corporate Code of Ethics
item.description: A statement that highlights an organization’s key ethical issues and identifies the overarching values and principles that are important tot the organization and it’s decision making

item.title: Corporate social responsibility
item.description: The concept that an organization should act ethically by taking responsibility for the impact of its actions on its shareholders, consumers, employees, community, environment, and suppliers

item.title: Cost-Benefit Analysis
item.description: Compares the cost to produce the product or service to the financial gain (or benefit) the organization stands to make as a result of executing the project.

item.title: Customer Data
item.description: Data that could be used to identify a customer, like employees, sales, and technical support contacts.

item.title: Customer Relationship Management
item.description: Software that helps businesses manage their relationships and interactions with their customers and future customers. CRMs aggregate data about the customer in one place and provide an efficient and practical way for the organization to interact with their customer.

item.title: Cyber Kill Chain
item.description: A framework that describes the stages of a cyber attack Reconnaissance Scoping out the target Weaponization Preparation of attack based on recon from previous step Could be payload code + exploit code Delivery Weaponized code is transmitted to target system Exploitation Weaponized code is executed on the system Installation Weaponized code runs a remote access tool (RAT) and achieves persistence on target system Command and control Outbound channel is established to remote server that allows the attacker to control the RAT Actions on objectives Access is used to collect information and exfiltrate information from target There could be other goals or motives See Also: [[MITRE ATT&CK]] and [[Diamond Model]]

item.title: Data at Rest
item.description: Data is in some sort of persistent storage media See also: Data in Transit and [[Data in Use]]

item.title: Data Classifications
item.description: Tags data so it can be managed through the Information Life Cycle A decision tree for applying one or more tags or labels to each data asset Tags usually based on the degree of confidentiality required Public (unclassified) No restrictions on viewing data No risk to organization if it is disclosed, but does pose a risk if it is modified or not available Confidential (secret) Information is highly sensitive, for viewing only by approved persons within the owner organization, and possibly by trusted third parties under [[NDA]] Critical (top secret) Information is too valuable to allow any risk of its capture.

item.title: Data Controller
item.description: Responsible for determining why and how data is stored, collected, and used and for ensuring that these purposes and means are lawful.

item.title: Data Custodian
item.description: Responsible for access control, encryption, and backup/recovery measures. Basically the guy who takes care of the hardware and storage aspect.

item.title: Data Disparity
item.description: Data gaps or lags that misrepresent reality

item.title: Data Exfiltraion
item.description: Unauthorized copying or retrieval of data from a system.

item.title: Data in Transit
item.description: Data that is being transmitted over a network actively. Also called data in motion, See also: Data at Rest and [[Data in Use]]

item.title: Data in Use
item.description: Data present in volatile memory, like system RAM or CPU registers or cache. See also: Data at Rest and Data in Transit

item.title: Data Loss Prevention
item.description: Keep that data safe Usually an automated tool Can protect [[Intellectual Property]] data Will usually consist of three components Policy Server to configure classification, confidentiality, and privacy rules and polices, log incidents, and compile reports Endpoint Agents to enforce policy on client computers, even when they are not connected to the network Network Agents to scan communications at network borders and interface with web and messaging servers to enforce policy DLP agents scan content in structured formats, like databases with a formal access control model DLP agents can also scan content in unstructured formats, like emails or word processing documents DLP agents can block the transfer of content if it does not conform to a predefined policy (Side note, this is probably what the Pope-blessed laptop used) Remediation The action a DLP software takes when it detects policy violation Alert only Block Quarantine Tombstone The file is quarantined and replaced with one describing the policy violation and how the user can release it again

item.title: Data Masking
item.description: A Database Deidentification Methods where generic or placeholder labels are substituted for real data while preserving the structure or format of the original data.

item.title: Data Minimization
item.description: The principle that data should only be processed and stored if that is necessary to perform the the purpose for which it is collected

item.title: Data Owner
item.description: A senior (executive) role with ultimate responsibility for maintaining the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the information asset. See also: Information Life Cycle Management, [[CIA Triad]], Data Controller, and Data Processor

item.title: Data Privacy Officer
item.description: Ensures that the processing, disclosure, and retention of PII ([[Personally Identifiable Information]]) complies with legal and regulatory frameworks See also: Data Roles and Responsibilities and Information Life Cycle Management

item.title: Data Processor
item.description: An entity engaged by the Data Controller to assist with technical collection, storage, or analysis tasks. Follows the instructions of the data controller with regard to collection or processing.

item.title: Data Retention
item.description: Backing up and archiving information assets to comply with business policies and/or applicable laws and regulations. Particularly affects financial data and security log data.

item.title: Data Roles and Responsibilities
item.description: A [[data governance]] policy describes the security controls that will be applied to protect data at each stage of its data life cycle.

item.title: Data Sharing and User Agreement
item.description: Personal data can only be collected for a specific purpose A legal means of preventing reidentification of pseudo-anonymized or deidentified data Specifies terms for the way a data set can be analyzed and proscribes the use of reidentification techniques See also: NDA, SLA, ISA, and Purpose Limitation

item.title: Data Sovereignty
item.description: The idea that a jurisdiction could prevent or restrict processing and storage of data on systems that do not physically reside within that jurisdiction.

item.title: Data Steward
item.description: Responsible for data quality, which involves tasks like making sure data is labeled and identified correctly with appropriate metadata and that data is collected and stored in a format and with values that comply with applicable laws and regulations.

item.title: Data Types
item.description: A data type schema usually applies more detailed labels than Data Classification. Personally Identifiable Information Data can be used to identify, contact, or locate and individual Several types of PII, including: SSN name date of birth email address telephone number street address biometric data Some information could be PII depending on context.

item.title: Database Deidentification Methods
item.description: Deidentification methods are usually implemented as part of the database management system hosting the data. Sensitive fields will be tagged for deidentification whenever a query or report is run.

item.title: Deontology
item.description: The ethical ideal of logical consistency and duty. To be moral is to do what it is your duty is.

item.title: Diamond Model
item.description: A framework for analyzing cybersecurity events Explores the relationships between adversary, capability, infrastructure, and victim

item.title: Differential Backups
item.description: A type of backup where all files modified since the last full backup and all new files are backed up.

item.title: Digital Forensics
item.description: The practice of collecting evidence from computer systems to a standard that will be accepted in a court of law

item.title: Discounted Cash Flow
item.description: Compares the value of the future worth of the project’s expected cash flows to today’s dollars, known as present value.

item.title: Discovery and Concept
item.description: The first phase in the Project Life Cycle. This phase determines whether the project is worthwhile. A Business Case is created to document the business need or justification for the project and will often include high0level details about estimated budgets and timelines for completing the project.

item.title: E-discovery
item.description: Procedures and tools to collect, preserve, and analyze digital evidence See Also: Chain of Custody and Digital Forensics

item.title: Edge Computing
item.description: Edge computing is devolved from [[Fog Computing]] and uses the following concepts: Edge devices collect and depend upon data for their operation, like a thermometer in an HVAC system collects temperature data which in turn is used by the HVAC system to turn the heating or air conditioning on or off.

item.title: Elasticity
item.description: Elasticity is the cloud computing concept of being able to flex resource needs to meet demands. For example, if your ecommerce site is expecting a lot of traffic, you could easily acquire more resources temporarily to accommodate said traffic.

item.title: Electronic Communications Privacy Act
item.description: Deals with three main issues: The protection of communications while in transfer from sender to receiver The protection of communications held in electronic storage The prohibition of devices from recording, dialing, routing, addressing, and signaling information about a search warrant Passed as an extension of the Wiretap Act

item.title: Electronic Health Record
item.description: A comprehensive view of the patient’s complete medical history designed to be shared with authorized providers and staff from more than one organization.

item.title: Electronic Medical Record
item.description: A collection of health-related information on an individual that is created, managed, and consulted by authorized clinicians and staff within a single healthcare organizations.

item.title: Enterprise Resource Planning
item.description: Systems that help companies coordinate their back-office business activities like accounting, procurement, human resources, and more. The idea is that one system provides functionality across the organizational functions and data can be easily shared, compared, and reported on.

item.title: Enterprise Risk Management
item.description: The comprehensive process of evaluating, measuring, and mitigating the many risks that pervade an organization. Often based on frameworks such as NIST’s Risk Management Framework or ISO 31K.

item.title: Equal Accuracy
item.description: The outcome where the same percentage of correct judgement is present in all groups

item.title: Equal Error
item.description: When the proportion of false acceptances is equal to the proportion of false rejections

item.title: Equal Representation
item.description: All groups are represented equally

item.title: Ethics
item.description: A societal code of behavior, what is generally accepted as “right”

item.title: Ethics in Tech Study Guide
item.description: Virtue Ethics Deontology Utilitarianism Kantian Ethics Consequentialism Relativism Ethics Morals Corporate Code of Ethics Supply chain sustainability Corporate social responsibility Wiretap Act Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act USA PATRIOT Act General Data Protection Regulation EU Data Protection Directive Electronic Communications Privacy Act Freedom of Information Act American Recovery and Reinvestment Act Fair Credit Reporting Act False Claims Act Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act Communications Decency Act Foreign Corrupt Practices Act Health Information Exchange Electronic Health Record Clinical Decision Support Electronic Medical Record Personal Health Record Misrepresentation Conflict of Interest Bribery Fraud Breach of Contract Protected Attribute Protected Class Statistical Parity Equal Accuracy Equal Representation Equal Error Data Disparity

item.title: EU Data Protection Directive
item.description: Requires any company doing business within the borders of the countries comprising the EU to implement a set of privacy directives on the fair and appropriate use of information

item.title: Executing
item.description: The executing phase is where the work of the project is performed and monitored for adherence to the project management plan.

item.title: Exposure Factor
item.description: The percentage of an asset value that would be lost during a security incident or disaster scenario

item.title: External Risk
item.description: A threat actor from outside an organization represents and external risk. External risks can also exist outside of cybersecurity. Natural disasters are one form of external risk.

item.title: Fair Credit Reporting Act
item.description: Regulates the operations of credit reporting bureaus, including how they collect, store, and use credit information. Designed to ensure the accuracy, fairness, and privacy of information gathered by the credit reporting companies and to provide guidelines for organizations whose systems that gather and sell information about people.

item.title: False Claims Act
item.description: AKA the Lincoln Law Enacted during the US Civil War to combat fraud by companies that sold supplies to the Union Army.

item.title: Fault Tolerance
item.description: Protection against system failure by providing extra (redundant) capacity. Generally, fault tolerant systems identify and eliminate single points of failure.

item.title: Feasibility Study
item.description: A study undertaken before the Business Case is written. Can determine whether the project is doable and likely to success. Examines the viability of the product, service, or result of the project.

item.title: Financial and Performance Analysis
item.description: A means to compare the benefits obtained from project requests by evaluating them using the same criteria. There are several financial and performance methods that evaluate benefits and rewards, such as :

item.title: Financial Information
item.description: Data held about bank and investment accounts, plus information such as payroll and tax returns. All about the money. Payment card information falls under financial information as well

item.title: Fog Computing
item.description: Developed by Cisco, fog computing places fog nodes using Wi-Fi, ZigBee, or 4G/5G to prioritize traffic, analyze and remediate alertable conditions, and backhaul remaining data to the data center for storage and low-priority analysis.

item.title: Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
item.description: Makes it a crime to bribe a foreign official, a foreign political part official, or a candidate for foreign political office.

item.title: Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act
item.description: Describes procedures for the electronic surveillance and collection of foreign intelligence information in communications between foreign governments or agents of foreign governments or foreign organizations.

item.title: Fraud
item.description: The crime of obtaining goods, services, or property through deception or trickery

item.title: Freedom of Information Act
item.description: Grants citizens the right to access certain information and records of federal, state, and local governments upon request. Enables journalists and the public to acquire information that the government is reluctant to release.

item.title: Full Backups
item.description: A type of backup where all selected data is backed up, regardless of when it was previously backed up.

item.title: General Data Protection Regulation
item.description: Designed to strengthen data protection of individuals within the EU by addressing the export of personal data outside the EU. This allows citizens to see and correct their personal data, and ensure data protection consistency across the EU

item.title: Geographical Considerations
item.description: Storage locations might have to be carefully selected to mitigate Data Sovereignty issues. Most cloud providers allow choice of data centers for processing and storage Employees needing access from multiple geographic locations can apply constraint-based access controls to validate the user’s geographic location before authorizing access

item.title: Government Data
item.description: Complex data collection and processing requirements for internal government agencies.

item.title: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act
item.description: Governs the collection, disclosure, and protection of consumers’ nonpublic personal information or Personally Identifiable Information Companies that offer financial products or services are the ones affected

item.title: Hashing and Salting
item.description: A method of producing a fixed-length string from arbitrary-length plaintext data using an algorithm, like SHA. It should be impossible to match the hash back to a plaintext.

item.title: Health Information Exchange
item.description: The process of sharing patient-level electronic health information between different organizations. The key to electronic exchange is the standardization of health data.

item.title: Hybrid Cloud
item.description: Hybrid clouds utilize on-premises resources combined with off-premises resources. Great for [[notes/Elasticity]] during intermittent busy seasons for smaller companies.

item.title: Hypervisor
item.description: A hypervisor is the system that allows Virtual Machines to be run. There are 2 types of hypervisor: Type 1 and Type 2.

item.title: Impact
item.description: The severity of the risk if realized as s security incident. Could be determined by value of the asset or the cost of disruption if the asset is compromised.

item.title: Impact Assessments
item.description: A data protection impact assessment is a process designed to identify the risks of collecting and processing personal data in the context of a business workflow or project and to identify mechanisms that mitigate those risks.

item.title: Incident Response Exercises
item.description: 3 main forms Tabletop Least costly Facilitator presents a scenario and the responders explain what action they would take Does not use computer systems Usually uses flashcards Walkthroughs Facilitator present a scenario, like in tabletop Responders demonstrate rather than explain what actions they would take Simulations Most costly Red team attempts and intrusion while blue team operates response and recovery controls White team moderates and evaluates the exercise

item.title: Incident Response Plan
item.description: Incident Response Plan Lists the procedures, contacts, and resources available to responders for various incident categories CIRT responsible for developing profiles or scenarios of typical incidents (DDoS, virus/worm outbreak, data exfiltration by an external adversary, etc) These profiles guide investigators in determining priorities and remediation plans [[CIRT]] could also be responsible for making a [[Playbook]] Assess for Severity Each incident has to be assessed and prioritized to allocate resources efficiently.

item.title: Incident Response Process
item.description: Defined by NIST 800.61r2, incident response follows a well-structure process. There are 6 principal stages in an incident response lifecycle.

item.title: Incremental Backups
item.description: A type of backup where only files modified since the last backup and new files are backed up.

item.title: Information Life Cycle Management
item.description: The information life cycle model Creation/collection data may be generated by an employee or automated system, or it may be submitted by a customer or supplier.

item.title: Initiating
item.description: The formal authorization for a new project to begin or for an existing project to continue into the next phase. This phase includes all the activities that lead up to the final authorization to begin the project.

item.title: Intellectual Property
item.description: Information created and owned by the company, usually about products or services they perform Also known as Proprietary Information Obvious target for a company’s competitors May represent a counterfeiting opportunity, like movies, music, and books See also: Personal Data, Sensitive Data, and Data Classifications

item.title: Intellectual Property Theft
item.description: The exfiltration of Intellectual Property. Stolen IP data loses much of its commercial value. Difficult to recover losses. See also: Risk Management and Enterprise Risk Management

item.title: Internal Rate of Return
item.description: The discount rate when the present value of the cash inflows equals the original investment. IRR states the profitability of an investment as an average percent over the life of the investment.

item.title: Internal Risk
item.description: Threats that can occur from inside the organization. Not always malicious. Includes contractors who were granted temp access. See also: Risk Management and Enterprise Risk Management

item.title: ISA
item.description: Interconnection Security Agreement Defined by NIST’s SP800-47 “Managing the Security of Information Exchanges”. Any federal agency interconnecting its IT system to a third party must create and ISA to govern the relationship

item.title: Kantian Ethics
item.description: See Deontology

item.title: Likelihood
item.description: The probability of a threat being realized See also: Impact

item.title: Misrepresentation
item.description: The misstatement or incomplete statement of material fact. If the misrepresentation causes the other party to enter into a contract, that party may have the legal right to cancel the contract or seek reimbursement for damages

item.title: MITRE ATT&CK
item.description: MITRE Corporation’s Adversarial Tactics, Techniques, and Common Knowledge A matrices of known TTPs Free at ( http://attack.mitre.org) Tags each technique with a unique ID and categorizes it by tactic Doesn’t assume how any adversary will run a campaign

item.title: Morals
item.description: Morals are personal principals, what guides you as an individual to what is “right”

item.title: Multiparty Risk
item.description: An adverse event that impacts multiple organizations. Typically arise from supplier relationships. Also referred to as ripple impacts. See also: Risk Management and Enterprise Risk Management

item.title: Multiprocessing
item.description: The running of two or more programs or sequences of instructions simultaneously by a computer with more than one CPU

item.title: NDA
item.description: Non-disclosure agreement Legal basis for protecting information assets Used between companies and employees, between companies and contractors, and between two companies If agreement is broken, there may be legal consequences Deter employees and contractors from violating the trust that an employer places in them See also: ISA, SLA, Data Sharing and User Agreement

item.title: Net Present Value
item.description: A cash flow technique that takes into account the differences in the value of money over time by calculating the revenues or cash flows the organization expects to receive over the life of the project in today’s dollars.

item.title: Operations
item.description: Operations are ongoing and repetitive, unlike Projects that have start and end dates. Operations typically involve ongoing functions that support the production of goods and services.

item.title: Order of Restoration
item.description: Enable and test power delivery systems Enable and test switch infrastructure, then routing appliance and systems Enable and test network security appliances Enable and test critical network servers Enable and test back-end and middleware, and then verify data integrity Enable and test front-end applications Enable client workstations and devices and client browser access

item.title: Payback Period
item.description: A cash flow technique that identifies the length of time it takes for the organization to recover all the costs of producing the project.

item.title: PCI DSS
item.description: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard defines the safe handling and storage of Financial Information

item.title: Personal Data
item.description: Information that relates to an individual identity See also Proprietary Information, Sensitive Data, and Data Classifications

item.title: Personal Health Information
item.description: Sensitive Data involving medical records, hospital results, insurance information, etc.

item.title: Personal Health Record
item.description: Includes the portions of the Electronic Health Record that are routinely shared with the patient, such as personal identifiers, contact information, health provider information, problem list, medication history, allergies, immunizations, and lab and test results.

item.title: Personally Identifiable Information
item.description: Any information that could reasonably identify an individual and must be subjected to regulatory standards. Different standards exist for different types of PII.

item.title: Planning
item.description: In the planning phase, the project goals, objectives, and deliverables are refined and broken down into manageable units of work. Project managers create time and cost estimates and determine resource requirements for each activity.

item.title: Playbook
item.description: A checkilst of actions to perform to detect and respond to a specific type of incident

item.title: Portfolios
item.description: A collection of Programs, sub-portfolios, and Projects that support strategic business goals or objectives. Unlike programs, portfolios may consist of projects that are not related

item.title: Privacy Notices
item.description: Personal data cannot be collected, processed, or retained without the individual’s informed consent. Privacy notices are a consent statement that lists the stated purpose for the collection and processing of data in plain language.

item.title: Privacy vs Security
item.description: Privacy Privacy requires that private data is identified, stored, processed, and retained in a way that is compliant with relevant regulations.

item.title: Program
item.description: A group of related Projects that are managed together using coordinated processes and techniques See also: Portfolios

item.title: Project
item.description: A project can be anything as long as it fits the following criteria: A project must be Unique. Every project involves doing something new, which means the end result should be a unique product or service Temporary: Projects must have defined start and end dates.

item.title: Project Life Cycle
item.description: Project management is performed in a series of phases that are executed to apply knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to the project activities to meet the project requirements.

item.title: Projects and Opperations
item.description: Projects come about to meet a specific, unique result. Once a project is completed, it is often handed off to Operations to manage the everyday tasks that the project implemented.

item.title: Proprietary Information
item.description: Information created and owned by the company, usually about products or services they perform Also known as Intellectual Property (IP) Obvious target for a company’s competitors May represent a counterfeiting opportunity, like movies, music, and books See also: Personal Data, Sensitive Data, and Data Classifications

item.title: Protected Attribute
item.description: Qualities, traits, or characteristics that, by law, cannot be discriminated against

item.title: Protected Class
item.description: Groups of people who are legally protected from being harmed or harrassed by laws, practices, or policies.

item.title: Purpose Limitation
item.description: The principle that personal information can be collected and processed only for a stated purpose to which the subject has consented.

item.title: Qualitative Risk Assessment
item.description: Focused on identifying significant risk factors. Based off of opinions of which risk factors are significant rather than calculations, like in Quantitative Risk Assessment.

item.title: Quantitative Risk Assessment
item.description: A form of risk assessment that aims to assign concrete values to each risk factor. Determining and assigning these values is complex and time consuming.

item.title: Qui Tam
item.description: A provision in the False Claims Act that allows a citizen to sue for fraud on behalf of the government

item.title: Redundancy
item.description: Overprovisioning resources at the component, host, and/or site level so that there is failover to a working instance in the event of a problem

item.title: Relativism
item.description: The idea that all norms and values are relative to the circumstances surrounding them See also: Virtue Ethics

item.title: Return On Investment
item.description: Measures the profitability of an investment and is often used to compare one investment to another. It measures the expected returns of the investment as compared to its costs and is displayed as a percentage.

item.title: Risk and Control Assessment
item.description: An external process to identify risks and the effectiveness with which controls mitigate those risks. Often performed through questionnaires and workshops with department managers.

item.title: Risk and Control Self-Assessment
item.description: An internal process undertaken by stakeholders to identify risks and the effectiveness with which controls mitigate those risks. Often performed through questionnaires and workshops with department managers/ The outcome of an RCSA is a report.

item.title: Risk Avoidance
item.description: The practice of stopping an activity that is risk-bearing. See Also: Risk Transference and Risk Management

item.title: Risk Management
item.description: Risk management is the process for identifying, assessing, and mitigation vulnerabilities and threats to the essential functions that a business must perform to serve its customers There are 5 main phases to risk management:

item.title: Risk Mitigation
item.description: The overall process of reducing exposure to or the effects of risk factors. See also: Risk Management

item.title: Risk Transference
item.description: Risk transference is the idea that utilizing cloud computing allows a company to transfer some degree of risk to another party.

item.title: Scalability
item.description: The ability to add more resources in parallel with existing resources or increase the power of existing resources See also: Elasticity

item.title: Scoring Model
item.description: A scoring model has a predefined list of criteria against which each alternative solution or project is rated. Each criterion is given both a scoring range and a weighting factor.

item.title: Sensitive Data
item.description: Typically used in context of Personal Data in which information about a subject could harm them if made public and could prejudice decisions made about the subject Defined by the GDPR, sensitive data includes: religious beliefs political opinions trade union membership gender sexual orientation racial or ethnic origin genetic data health information

item.title: Single Loss Expectancy
item.description: The amount that would be lost in a single occurrence of the risk factor. This is determined by multiplying the value of the asset by an Exposure Factor

item.title: SLA
item.description: Service Level Agreement A contractual agreement setting out the detailed terms under which a service is provided. Can include terms for security access controls and risk assessments, plus processing requirement for confidential and private data

item.title: Software Design Lifecycle
item.description: There are 4 main phases to the software development lifecycle: Analysis This is the practice of determining the goals for a program The “Why” Design Design determines the specifics of how to build a program The “What” Implementation Implementation builds the program according to the design The “How” Testing Testing checks that the program meets the goal There are 2 main methods of implementing the software development lifecycle: the [[notes/Waterfall Approach]] and the [[notes/Agile Approach]].

item.title: Stakeholders
item.description: Anyone who has a vested interest in the project. Can include individuals and organizations, and both the project sponsor and the project manager are considered stakeholders.

item.title: Statistical Parity
item.description: A natural way to model equity: members of each group have the same chance or receiving the favorable output

item.title: Supply chain sustainability
item.description: A component of Corporate social responsibility that focuses on developing and maintaining a supply chain that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their needs

item.title: Threat
item.description: A potential negative action or event that utilizes a Vulnerability to cause harm to a system. Not always malicious

item.title: Tokenization
item.description: Database Deidentification Methods where a unique token is substituted for data.

item.title: USA PATRIOT Act
item.description: Passed after 9/11, it gave sweeping new powers to both domestic law enforcement and U.S. international intelligence agency, including increasing the ability of law enforcement agencies to search telephone, email, medical, financial, and other records.

item.title: Utilitarianism
item.description: Jeremy Bentham believed that a moral action is one that produces the most pleasure for everyone concerned.

item.title: Virtual Desktop
item.description: Virtual desktops are essentially hosted VMs that a client connects to for OS access. The clients are typically not very resource-equipped and are referred to as “thin clients.

item.title: Virtual Machines
item.description: A way to virtualize desktops for many different purposes. Virtual Machines (VMs) can be implemented to run software with other OS dependencies, as a means of sandboxing for security purposes, for training, or for thin client and [[Virtual Desktop]] environments.

item.title: Virtue Ethics
item.description: Aristotle’s philosophy that the ethical thing to do is dependent on the context of the decision required. It prioritizes “fitting in” to society rather than what is morally correct for the individual

item.title: Vulnerabilities
item.description: A weakness in an IT system that can be exploited by a threat actor See also: Threat

item.title: Waterfall Approach
item.description: The Software Development Lifecycle approach that involves delivering the project all at once. Categorized by longer development time, this approach is relatively rigid and aims to deliver the final product all at once.

item.title: Wiretap Act
item.description: AKA Title III of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act, this act regulates the interception of wire and oral communications.
